metadata.case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 2060 of 1971, 67, 139 and 393 of 1972 and WP No. 287 of 1973
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 2060 of 1971, 67, 139 and 393 of 1972; WRIT PETITION No. 287 of 1973

facts.text: The above appeals were disposed of by this Court on 16-8-1972. The Court set aside the seniority list prepared by the Department on 15-7-1968 and gave directions as to how the same was to be prepared.

Principal point decided in previous appeals: validity of the quota rule and the seniority rule in their operation after 15-1-1959. Court held that on Government's decision to promote a large number of Income-tax Officers from Class II to Class I, the quota rule (66-1/2% direct recruits, 33-1/2% promotees) lapsed and with it the seniority rule giving weightage of 2 to 3 years to promotees broke down.

Court directed Government to devise a just and fair seniority rule from 16-1-1959, in consultation with UPSC if necessary. Seniority list from 1951 to 15-1-1959 per old quota and seniority rules; from 16-1-1959 per new rule.
Court directed respondents (Union of India, Ministry of Finance, Central Board of Direct Taxes) to prepare fresh seniority list and file in court within six months.
On February 9, 1973, President under proviso to Article 309 made Income-tax Officers (Class I) Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1973 effective from 16-1-1959.

New seniority rule (Rule 3): Seniority among promotees inter se by order of selection; direct recruits by merit order; relative seniority in 1:1 ratio per roster: promotee, direct recruit, promotee, direct recruit, etc.
Department prepared new seniority list per directions and filed in court on February 15, 1973.
Seniority till 15-1-1959 (serial 1-485) undisputed and per old rules.
If new rule valid, rest of list to serial 1717 correct.
In 1950s, several years promotees appointed in excess of quota (1956-1958), irregular but regularized later when quota posts available.
73 promotees (spill-overs) appointed 1956-1958 had no quota posts for absorption on 16-1-1959; plus subsequent promotees to be absorbed.
Court directed spill-overs absorbed on priority basis.
New list: 1-485 pre-16-1-1959 per old rules; 486-1717 per new rule, alternating promotee (even serials) and direct recruit (odd serials). All promotees below 485 are spill-overs or later promotees.
214 officers promoted 1959-1962 after upgrading equal Class II posts.
No promotions in 1963, 1965, 1967-1970 to absorb earlier promotees.
All promotees appointed on officiating/ad hoc basis, informed seniority under consideration.
Government considered 4 alternatives for new rule, chose 1:1 roster as fairest.

legal_issues.text: Validity of the new seniority rule (Income-tax Officers Class I Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1973) - whether unjust, unfair, and violative of Article 16.
Whether spill-over promotees entitled to block seniority from 16-1-1959 ahead of direct recruits.
Whether promotees' appointments valid under Rule 4 of 1945 Recruitment Rules post quota lapse, entitling them to seniority from appointment dates without alteration.
Whether new rule just and fair as directed by Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: New rule invalid as unjust, unfair, and violative of Article 16; spill-overs should be placed in block on 16-1-1959 ahead of direct recruits that year.
At least 10 spill-overs accommodable pre-16-1-1959 as slight deviation from quota.
Post quota lapse, promotees deemed validly appointed under Rule 4 of 1945 Recruitment Rules; natural seniority from appointment dates cannot be altered retrospectively, violates Article 16.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 4 Income-tax Officers Class I Grade II Service Recruitment Rules 1945; Article 16

petitioner_arguments.text: New rule not just/fair; should give weightage to promotees considering age, experience, reduced higher promotion chances.
Fairer: seniority by appointment dates, spill-overs on 16-1-1959.

respondent_arguments.text: New rule follows Court directions; allocates posts 1:1 roster, absorbs spill-overs without prejudice to their inter se seniority.
Appointments irregular without allocated posts; new rule regularizes from 16-1-1959.
Rule outcome of consultation; 4 alternatives considered, 1:1 roster fairest, avoids block disadvantages.
50% promotee quota gain for them; no weightage needed for harmony.

court_reasoning.text: Quota and old seniority rules lapsed 16-1-1959 creating void; new rule necessary substitute to allocate posts and fix seniority for service continuity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Service constituted on principles requiring post allocation between sources and inter se seniority rules.

court_reasoning.text: Spill-overs not entitled to block priority over direct recruits; to be governed by new rule like all post-15-1-1959 entrants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Priority meant no prejudice by later promotees, not exemption from seniority rule.

court_reasoning.text: Appointments irregular sans allocated posts; quota lapse did not auto-regularize; new rule provides posts and seniority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officiating/ad hoc with pending seniority notice; no vested right in irregular dates.

court_reasoning.text: New rule just/fair: Govt policy on ratio/experience; 1:1 avoids blocks, better than old quota/weightage; overall view, not individual impact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt best judge of public interest/ratio; promotes harmony.

court_reasoning.text: No Art 16 violation: adjustment for integration, not post-entry classification; precedents inapplicable as no integrated cadre pre-rule.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Seniority fix essential for promotions from integrated cadre.

holdings.text: New seniority rule valid, not violative of Article 16; seniority list of 15-2-1973 correct per Court directions.

precedents_cited.relevance: Quota rule lapsed; no valid appointments outside quota.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mervyn Coutinho Ors. v. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Once integrated in grade, no birth marks for higher promotion seniority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Roshan Lal v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Reaffirmed Mervyn Coutinho; no light on inter se seniority pre-integration.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. M. Pandit and Anr. v. State of Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: No discrimination in promotion from integrated cadre of same designation/pay.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art 16: equality in public employment, no violation; Art 32: enforcement; Art 309: rules framed by President.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Officers (Class I) Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1973
Income-tax Officers Class I Grade II Service Recruitment Rules, 1945
statutes_cited.legal_basis: Promotee appointments; not auto-valid post quota lapse.

outcome.summary: Court accepted the new seniority list filed on 15-2-1973 as correct in accordance with directions in judgment dated 16-8-1972; upheld validity of new seniority rules.
outcome.relief_granted: Seniority list approved; proceedings arising from mandamus fulfilled.

key_quotes.text: "Since the old seniority rule has ceased to operate by reason of the infringement of the quota rule it will be for the Government to devise... a just and fair seniority rule... from 16-1-1959."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The new seniority rule, therefore, was a substitute rule very necessary... for maintaining its continuity as a well-regulated cadre."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies necessity and validity of new rule.

key_quotes.text: "We think it is [just and fair]. Since the seniority list Annexure B filed on 15-2-1973 is in accordance with the directions... we accept it as the correct seniority list."
key_quotes.speaker: court
